title: Claim 'dozens' of Volkswagen bosses knew about emissions cheating
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Oct 14, 2015, 18:37 BST - UK Markets closed Claim 'dozens' of Volkswagen bosses knew about emissions cheating By Alan Tovey | Telegraph – 28 minutes ago 148.85 +3.80 
Scandal over Volkswagen (Other OTC: VLKAF - news ) emissions intensifies with report up to 30 bosses knew about it despite executives claims they were unaware 
Dozens of managers are claimed to have known about Volkswagen cheating emissions tests, putting fresh pressure on management at the beleaguered car maker. 
The company has admitted that 11m of its VW, Audi (LSE: 0FG8.L - news ) , SEAT and Skoda cars were fitted with “defeat devices” which allowed them to cheat pollution checks. 
However, VW’s executives have so far refused to say who knew about the scandal but now German reports claim that at least 30 bosses were involved. 
VW commissioned an external investigation by law firm Jones Day and German magazine Spiegel cited early findings from its report to come up with the number, adding that dozens of managers face suspension. 
Citing a person "familiar with the matter", Spiegel claimed that the number of bosses who knew about the scandal could grow. 
However, VW denied the claims, with a spokesman saying: "This number is completely unfounded." 
Martin Winterkorn, the former chief executive who quit last month after VW’s deceit hit the headlines, said in his resignation statement that he was leaving “in the interests of the company even though I am not aware of any wrongdoing on my part”. 
Giving evidence to MPs on Monday, Paul Willis, VW’s managing director in the UK, denied that VW’s executives were aware of the scam, saying: "I find it absolutely implausible that senior people in the company would have known of these issues with regard to the testing regime." 
His remarks echoed his US counterpart Michael Horn who told US lawmakers that the defeat devices were fitted by “a couple of software engineers who put this in for whatever reason”. 
VW Group chief executive Matthias Mueller is due to meet with the company's top bosses on Thursday to discuss the investigation into events that allowed defeat devices to be fitted to its cars and plan the company's future strategy. 
The news came as the car company faced fresh problems as it revealed to US regulators that its 2016 diesel models have additional software on them which could help beat emissions controls. 
VW confirmed that the diesels are fitted with an "auxiliary emissions control device" which is different to the defeat devices which caused VW's share prices to plunge and cost Mr Winterkorn to resign. 
The new software causes the catalyst which controls the amount of pollution the engines pump out to heat up faster, improving the catalyst's ability to limit Nox emissions. 
A spokesman for the car maker said it first told the US Environmental Protection Agency and California regulators about the existence of the software last week. 
Regulators have yet to rule if the latest software is specifically to beat tests and all such devices have to be revealed to authorities if cars are to receive the certification required for them to go on sale in the US. 
VW could suffer a heavy financial blow unless it can get the green light from regulators to sell its diesel vehicles, with the company currently having imposed a moratorium on sales of affected vehicles. 
Back in VW's home market, German environment minister Barbara Hendricks called for tougher emissions regulations as a result of the scandal. 
In a position paper Social Democrat Ms Hendricks said she wanted to see controls "so exacting in future that diesel will really be cleaner due to them". 
"Companies need to learn that in the long-term they can't evade environmental protection, which is necessary," she said, adding that diesel engines could only have a viable future if auto makers could prove it could "make them really clean". 
VW's North America management is also due for a rejig with Winfried Vahland, currently chairman of Skoda's board of directors but expected to take a senior role in the US, set to leave the company. 
Mr Vahland is said to be leaving due to differences of opinion over VW's strategy in America.
